content: Whenever the administering authority revokes the determination that a foreign country is a nonmarket economy country, the President must notify the Senate and House committees, request a joint resolution be introduced, and a joint resolution shall be introduced in Congress. The term "joint resolution" refers to a resolution of the 2 Houses of Congress. A joint resolution introduced in Congress approves the change of nonmarket economy status for products of a specific country, as notified by the President to the Senate and House committees. The resolution must be introduced by the majority leader of the House of Representatives or designated members. A joint resolution introduced in Congress approves the change of nonmarket economy status for products of a specific country, as notified by the President to the Senate and House committees. The resolution must be introduced by the majority leader of the House, or designated members, and in the Senate by the majority leader or designated members. No amendments are allowed to the resolution in either House, and there is a 45-day period for committee consideration. The joint resolution must be voted on within 15 days of being reported by the committee or automatically discharged after 45 days for further consideration. If both Houses receive the same joint resolution, the procedure remains the same. Floor consideration in the House for a joint resolution is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate is limited to 20 minutes. Floor consideration in the House for a joint resolution is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate is limited to 20 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the resolution. Motion to limit debate or recommit the resolution is not allowed. Motions to postpone or proceed to other business are decided without debate. Appeals on procedural rules related to the resolution are decided without debate. Floor consideration in the Senate for a joint resolution is privileged and not debatable. Debate is limited to 20 hours, with no amendments allowed to the motion. Reconsidering the motion vote is also not permitted. The Senate limits debate on joint resolutions to 20 hours, divided between majority and minority leaders. Debate on motions or appeals is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and manager, with additional time allotted by leaders if needed. The Senate limits debate on joint resolutions to 20 hours, divided between majority and minority leaders. Other motions in the Senate to further limit debate are not debatable. A motion to recommit a joint resolution is not in order. Rules of the House of Representatives and Senate are enacted by Congress as an exercise of their rulemaking power, applicable only with respect to the procedure to be followed in each House in the case of joint resolutions. The rules of the House and Senate can be changed at any time, similar to any other rule of the respective House, while still respecting constitutional rights. SEC. 4. STUDY AND REPORT ON SUBSIDIES BY PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA. The United States International Trade Commission will conduct a study on how China uses government intervention to promote investment, employment, and exports. The study will catalog practices and policies used by Chinese government bodies to influence decision-making in manufacturing enterprises. Topics include privatization, nonperforming loans, price coordination, targeted industry assistance, banking, finance, utility rates, infrastructure, and taxation. The United States International Trade Commission will conduct a study on how China uses government intervention to promote investment, employment, and exports, including infrastructure development, taxation, restraints on imports and exports, research and development, worker training, and rationalization of uneconomic enterprises. Congress requests the completion of the study within 9 months of the Act's enactment, with a report submitted to relevant committees and the public. Additionally, the Commission is to prepare and submit annual reports through 2017. The International Trade Commission will update and submit a report to relevant committees and the public.
